source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: EUROGATE's Terms & Conditions apply to goods handling, storage, and all other services undertaken by EUROGATE, unless statutory regulations require otherwise.

source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: Client must use forms provided by HHLA or EDI for data transmission necessary for services.

source_document: Hafen Hamburg e.V. - Kaibetriebsordnung Analysis
regulation_detail: Customer is recommended to use quay operator's printed forms or EDI for application data transfer. EDI preferred if available.

source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: Orders for goods handling must be submitted by EDI or exceptionally in text form using stipulated forms/templates.

source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: Shipping agent should submit manifest to HHLA at least 48 hours before discharge starts.

source_document: Hafen Hamburg e.V. - Kaibetriebsordnung Analysis
regulation_detail: Shipping agent is recommended to submit manifest at least one day before discharge.

source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: Prior to delivery of containerized cargoes, customer/deliverer must provide Cargo Information Checklist (Containerized) including: Customer name, Ship name, Voyage number, Container number, Size/Type, Gross/Net weight, Empty/Full status, Port of discharge, Hazardous-goods designation, Temperature, Excess dimensions, Booking number.

source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: Booking number: Ship booking number of the container operator, same as on transport documents. Required for standard export container deliveries with booking number.

source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: If goods are dangerous goods, delivering party must inform receiving party (HHLA) at least 48 hours in advance.

source_document: Hafen Hamburg e.V. - Kaibetriebsordnung Analysis
regulation_detail: Quay operator is recommended to be supplied with dangerous goods data before delivery (export/import), including: Danger class/sub-class, UN No., Technical name, Gross weight, net explosive weight, Packaging type, packaging group.

source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: For reefer containers, Client must announce as reefer Container for power supply connection at least 24 hours in advance and provide written cooling-order to HHLA email address.

source_document: Waltershof Customs Office - Information on Temporary Storage and General German Customs Clearance
regulation_detail: Goods in customs seaport are under customs supervision and placed under temporary storage upon arrival (AT/B number).

source_document: Waltershof Customs Office - Information on Temporary Storage and General German Customs Clearance
regulation_detail: A valid EORI (Economic Operators Registration and Identification) number is mandatory for businesses engaging in import activities within the EU, including Germany.

source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: Customer duties include supplying ship report at least 24 hours prior to arrival using local information channels.

source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: For handling towards Sea Going Vessels, customs presentation data must be presented to customs by Client, and customs receipt acknowledged via ZAPP-System number.

regulation_subcategory: TR02 System - CUSCAR Data via EDI
source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: Client shall provide all data necessary for custom-processing as defined in latest CUSCAR Guidelines (released by HHLA). All data to be transmitted by EDI before vessel discharge.

source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: Haulage company submits transport and container data along with a status request (TR02 message).

source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: Status Code 100 OK: The pre-announcement is correct; all prerequisites for self-service terminal handling with the pre-announcement number (PAN) have been met.

source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: Rule 1 - PAN Essential: Drivers must keep their pre-announcement number (PAN) handy at all times. Containers will only be handled using this number.

source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: Slots are mandatory for all container transport subject to mandatory pre-announcement. A valid time window is needed before processing can be carried out at the terminal.

source_document: HHLA - Occupational Health and Safety Regulations for External Companies Analysis
regulation_detail: HHLA's External Company Coordinator coordinates work and requires joint risk assessment with Contractor representatives before work starts to avoid reciprocal danger.

source_document: HHLA - Occupational Health and Safety Regulations for External Companies Analysis
regulation_detail: Contractor must carry job ticket on premises from arrival to departure. Job ticket documents responsible persons, briefing, risk assessment, and HHLA go-ahead.

source_document: HHLA - Occupational Health and Safety Regulations for External Companies Analysis
regulation_detail: Entry/presence at work place only with appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Contractor ensures PPE provision and mandatory usage.

source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: EUROGATE General Terms and Conditions of Business do not explicitly state a specific manifest submission deadline before vessel discharge.  General port practices and timely operations would necessitate submission at least 24-48 hours prior to discharge, similar to HHLA and industry recommendations. Consult EUROGATE directly for specific requirements.

regulation_subcategory: Manifest Submission - Consequences of Late Submission
source_document: To be generated from EUROGATE & HHLA T&C and Kaibetriebsordnung Analysis
regulation_detail: The analyzed documents do not explicitly detail specific financial penalties for late manifest submission. However, late submission is implied to cause operational disruptions and potential delays, which could lead to indirect costs for the shipping agent or client due to slower processing and potential berthing delays.  Both HHLA and Kaibetriebsordnung emphasize the *importance* of timely manifest submission for efficient operations.

source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024
regulation_detail: The location of the 'List of Commodities' is not explicitly provided within the HHLA Quay Tariff document analysis.  To access the 'List of Commodities' for detailed handling charges, logistics professionals should consult the *official HHLA Quay Tariff document directly or contact HHLA customer service* for the most up-to-date version and access information.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Free Time - Import Containers
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff provides *3 calendar days of free quayside storage for import containers*, starting after the last day of discharge by the seagoing ship.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Free Time - Export Containers
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff provides *5 calendar days of free quayside storage for export containers*, starting after the delivery date of the cargo.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Free Time - Transhipment Containers
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff provides *7 calendar days of free quayside storage for transhipment containers*, defined as shipments arriving by sea and intended for further despatch by sea according to the Bill of Lading. Free time starts from the delivery date of the cargo.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Free Time - Import Containers - EUROGATE
source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: Information on EUROGATE free storage periods for import containers is *not found* in the analyzed EUROGATE General Terms & Conditions of Business.  Consult EUROGATE's official tariff documents or contact EUROGATE directly for details on import container free storage periods.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Free Time - Export Containers - EUROGATE
source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: Information on EUROGATE free storage periods for export containers is *not found* in the analyzed EUROGATE General Terms & Conditions of Business. Consult EUROGATE's official tariff documents or contact EUROGATE directly for details on export container free storage periods.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Free Time - Transhipment Containers - EUROGATE
source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis
regulation_detail: Information on EUROGATE free storage periods for transhipment containers is *not found* in the analyzed EUROGATE General Terms & Conditions of Business. Consult EUROGATE's official tariff documents or contact EUROGATE directly for details on transhipment container free storage periods.

regulation_subcategory: Storage Charges - Hazardous Containers - IMO Class 1 & 7
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff specifies a *daily storage charge of €181.50 per container* for containers containing hazardous goods of IMO Classes 1 and 7.  Notably, *no free time is granted* for storage of these highly hazardous containers.

regulation_subcategory: Dangerous Goods - IMO Class 1 & 7 Handling Regulations
source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: HHLA GTCCH mandates that handling and transport of dangerous goods, including IMO Classes 1 and 7, must fully comply with the Port Safety Regulation (“GGBVOHH”) and the Port Traffic and Shipping Act of Hamburg.  Specific handling regulations for IMO Class 1 and 7 are *not explicitly detailed within the GTCCH itself*; refer to GGBVOHH and Port Traffic and Shipping Act for detailed regulations.

regulation_subcategory: Change of Depositary - ATLAS Electronic Submission
source_document: Waltershof Customs Office - Information on Temporary Storage and General German Customs Clearance (and Perplexity Search Result Summary)
regulation_detail: The change of depositary at Waltershof Customs Office is *primarily an electronic process via ATLAS*. Key steps include: 1) Electronic submission of change request referencing the original AT/B number. 2) Provision of new depositary's authorization details and container identification data within the ATLAS system. 3) Electronic processing and validation by customs authorities within ATLAS, without need for paper documents in standard cases.

regulation_subcategory: Change of Depositary - Paper Fallback - Form HH 0339-E
source_document: Waltershof Customs Office - Information on Temporary Storage and General German Customs Clearance (and Perplexity Search Result Summary)
regulation_detail: Form HH 0339-E ('Antrag auf Lagerortverlegung' - Application for Change of Storage Location) serves as the *paper-based fallback* for change of depositary requests at Waltershof Customs Office when electronic ATLAS submission is not possible.  Key sections include: Details of the original temporary storage (AT/B number), identification of the current and new depositary, container information, and required signatures and authorizations.  Submission to Waltershof Customs Office is required.

regulation_subcategory: EORI Number - Mandatory for Import & Temporary Storage
source_document: Waltershof Customs Office - Information on Temporary Storage and General German Customs Clearance (and Perplexity Search Result Summary)
regulation_detail: A valid EORI (Economic Operators Registration and Identification) number is *mandatory* for all businesses acting as depositaries or requesting change of depositary for import shipments into Hamburg, *including goods under temporary storage*.  EORI is essential for identification and legal compliance in EU customs procedures.

regulation_subcategory: EORI Number - Obtaining Procedure in Germany
source_document: Perplexity Search Result Summary (FAQ 2 - "Obtaining EORI")
regulation_detail: To obtain an EORI number in Germany, businesses must apply to the *German Customs Authority (Zoll)*. The application process typically takes *3-5 business days*.  Applications are generally submitted *electronically* via the Zoll portal.  Ensure all required company information and registration details are accurately provided to avoid delays.

regulation_subcategory: Working Hours - Standard Quay Operations - HHLA
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024
regulation_detail: Standard working hours for quay operations at HHLA terminals are *not explicitly defined* in the HHLA Quay Tariff document analysis. However, the tariff structure implies standard weekday working hours as the basis for regular rates, with surcharges applied for work outside these hours (night shifts, weekends, holidays).  Consult HHLA directly for precise standard working hour definitions.

source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024 (Section V - Special Charges - (1) Surcharge for work outside normal working hours)
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff applies substantial surcharges for work outside normal weekday working hours. Examples include: *Night shifts (Mon-Thu): €1,752.80 per gang/shift*; *First shift on Saturdays: €1,385.30 per gang/shift*; *Shifts on Sundays/Holidays: €3,287.20 per gang/shift*.  Detailed surcharge rates vary by shift type and are listed in Section V of the HHLA Quay Tariff.

regulation_subcategory: Reefer Container Services - Energy Supply Charge
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024 (Section VIII - Charges for the Container Handling - (5) Reefer container services - b) Energy supply)
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff specifies a *daily energy supply charge for reefer containers of €113.00 per container per 24 hours*. This charge is *in addition to* reception/delivery and storage charges.

regulation_subcategory: Special Containers - Reefer Containers - Cooling Order Details
source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: HHLA GTCCH requires a *written cooling order* for reefer containers requiring power supply, sent to a Company-specified email address *prior to arrival*.  Key details to include in the cooling order: *Container number*, *temperature set point*, and *any other information requested by the Company*. The cooling order ensures proper temperature maintenance during terminal stay.

source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis
regulation_detail: For truck arrivals *more than 90 minutes outside* the booked slot (Priority 3), the HHLA TR02 User Manual mandates *re-booking of the slot before arrival*.  Trucks arriving in Priority 3 *will not be cleared for terminal entry without prior re-booking*, and waiting in the terminal parking area for processing without a valid slot is *not permitted*.

regulation_subcategory: Customs & Special Services - CPA Inspection Charges
source_document: HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis - December 1st, 2024 (Section VIII - Charges for the Container Handling - (11) Customs and special services - e) transport to the CPA)
regulation_detail: HHLA Quay Tariff specifies a charge for 'transport to the CPA (Container Screening Center)' of *€346.90 per container*. This charge is *additional to* other potential charges including: *€56.30 per started ½ hour after 30 mins free waiting time at CPA*, *truck toll*, and *IMO charge of €74.70 for hazardous goods*.

regulation_subcategory: Customs Inspection - CPA (Container Screening Center) Procedure
source_document: To be generated -  Information on CPA Inspection procedure is likely *not* in HHLA Tariff or User Manual.
regulation_detail: The analyzed HHLA documents do not detail the exact step-by-step procedure for customs inspections at the Container Screening Center (CPA) in Hamburg.  *Typical general steps* in a customs inspection at a CPA (based on common logistics practices) would likely include: 1) *Transport of container to CPA*. 2) *Presentation of required customs documentation*. 3) *Unloading and scanning of container contents* by customs officials. 4) *Potential physical inspection* of goods. 5) *Communication of inspection results*. 6) *Re-loading of container*. 7) *Customs release or further actions* depending on inspection outcome.

regulation_subcategory: NCTS Transit Procedure (T1) - German Procedures at Collection
source_document: Waltershof Customs Office - Information on Temporary Storage and General German Customs Clearance (and Perplexity Search Result Summary)
regulation_detail: The analyzed documents do not provide a step-by-step guide to German customs procedures for T1 transit *collections* specifically at Hamburg terminals. However, based on general NCTS T1 procedure and Waltershof Customs Office information, key elements likely include: 1) *Haulage company initiates T1 transit procedure electronically via ATLAS (or through a customs broker)*. 2) *Presentation of Transit Accompanying Document (TAD) or MRN (Movement Reference Number) to customs at the terminal*. 3) *Potential customs inspection or verification of T1 documents*. 4) *Customs endorsement/release for transit*. 5) *Haulage company proceeds with transport under T1 to destination customs office for clearance*.

regulation_subcategory: Source Document - HHLA General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH)
source_document: Web Search Result - Action 5.3.b from previous research questions - To be determined by web search
regulation_detail: Official source document URL for HHLA General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) *not found* through web search in English or German. Consult HHLA directly (via contact details in Section XI of the HHLA Quay Tariff Analysis document) to request access to the official GTCCH document.

regulation_subcategory: Source Document - EUROGATE General Terms & Conditions of Business
source_document: Web Search Result - Action 5.3.b from previous research questions - To be determined by web search
regulation_detail: Official source document URL for EUROGATE Hamburg General Terms & Conditions of Business *not found* through web search in English or German. Consult EUROGATE directly (via contact details on EUROGATE website) to request access to the official Terms and Conditions document.

regulation_subcategory: Claim Limitation Period - Cargo Damage/Loss - HHLA
source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis (Section VI - § 17 Limitation Period)
regulation_detail: HHLA GTCCH stipulates a *one-year limitation period* for *all claims against HHLA*, including cargo damage or loss, commencing at the end of the delivery day (or day goods should have been delivered).  An *exception* exists for cases of *intent or gross negligence*, where the limitation period is extended to *three years*.

regulation_subcategory: Claim Limitation Period - Cargo Damage/Loss - EUROGATE
source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis (Section IV - Article 27 Limitation of Claim)
regulation_detail: EUROGATE Terms & Conditions stipulate a *one-year limitation period* for *all claims against EUROGATE*, including property damage and cargo damage/loss, commencing upon expiry of the delivery day (or day goods ought to have been delivered). An *exception* exists for cases of *intent or equivalent fault*, where the limitation period is extended to *three years*.

regulation_subcategory: Special Containers - OOG Containers - Additional Documentation
source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis (Section 3.3.2)
regulation_detail: The HHLA TR02 User Manual indicates that for OOG containers, 'Full transport documentation including the oversize dimensions must be presented' during manual pre-check (MPC).  *Specific additional documents beyond standard transport documentation are not explicitly listed in the analyzed HHLA documents*. Consult HHLA directly for detailed documentation requirements for specific OOG shipments.

regulation_subcategory: Special Containers - OOG Containers - Pre-Approval Steps
source_document: HHLA - General Terms and Conditions for Container Handling (GTCCH) Analysis
regulation_detail: Analyzed HHLA documents, including the GTCCH and TR02 User Manual, *do not explicitly detail specific pre-approval *steps* beyond standard TR02 pre-announcement for OOG containers*.  Handling of OOG containers requires manual pre-check (MPC), implying a more detailed review by HHLA operations staff.  For large or complex OOG shipments, *proactive consultation with HHLA operations department prior to pre-announcement is highly recommended* to clarify handling procedures and potential pre-approval needs.

regulation_subcategory: TR02 System - Alternative Data Exchange - Web Application (Truckgate)
source_document: HHLA - Pre-announcement of Truck Visits - User Manual Analysis (Section 2.2 - Web Application)
regulation_detail: As an alternative to EDI, HHLA TR02 system offers a *free 'Web Application'* accessible via web browser (web.truckgate.de) or mobile app (mobile.truckgate.de).  This Web Application, requiring a valid trucker card, provides a *user-friendly interface for truck drivers* to directly input pre-announcement data and manage slot bookings, potentially serving as a suitable alternative for smaller haulage companies without EDI infrastructure.

source_document: EUROGATE Hamburg - General Terms & Conditions of Business Analysis (Section I - Article 2 (1)) and potentially Hafen Hamburg KBO (Section I - § 2 (3))
regulation_detail: EUROGATE Terms and Conditions mention that customers must use 'forms provided by the Company or, if requested by the Company, EDI for transmission of all data'. This *implies that paper-based forms are a *less preferred but potentially accepted* alternative data exchange method at EUROGATE, especially for customers who may not have EDI capabilities.  However, EDI is clearly the *standard and preferred method* for data exchange at EUROGATE and across Hamburg ports (as per Kaibetriebsordnung recommendation), and using paper forms may lead to less efficient processing.
Hamburg Port Authority (HPA) manages the Port of Hamburg and emphasizes smartPORT digitalization initiatives.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Investigate 'Information Sheet concerning Notice of Arrival/Departure' and 'Port Information Guide 2021' for vessel arrival procedures at Port of Hamburg.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Transhipment manifest required for in-port container transfers at Port of Hamburg, processed via EDI/IMP application.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Hazardous cargo notification to port authorities required at least 12 hours prior to arrival AND upon arrival at the terminal in Port of Hamburg.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Port of Hamburg is transitioning to a digital 'authorization for pick-up' system for container release, replacing PIN codes.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Master of vessel arriving in Port of Hamburg from foreign ports must transmit crew/passenger lists and last 10 ports of call 24 hours prior to arrival in Hamburg.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Harbour Master's Division of HPA is the key contact for vessel arrival inquiries at Port of Hamburg.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: German Customs Authority (Zoll) administers customs regulations for Port of Hamburg.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: Entry Summary Declaration (ENS) must be submitted at least 24 hours before loading in foreign port for maritime cargo arriving in Hamburg, as a mandatory customs requirement.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: BAFA (Federal Office for Economic Affairs and Export Control) oversees export control regulations, potentially relevant for cargo arriving in Hamburg that is also subject to export controls.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report

regulation_detail: BMEL (Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture) regulates import conditions and certifications for specific cargo types like food products in Germany and Port of Hamburg.
source_document: Comparative Analysis Report
